newsitem.title: GERMANY: Siemens sticks to sick pay cuts move.
newsitem.headline: Siemens sticks to sick pay cuts move.

text.p: German engineering group Siemens AG said on Tuesday it would go ahead with implementing sick pay cuts of 20 percent made possible by rules which have now come into force.
The company rejected an earlier statement by the IG Metall trade union that it had decided to maintain full sick pay, but said it was ready to negotiate with union leaders on the issue.
A spokesman told Reuters in Munich that the sick pay reductions would be phased in on the company payroll by the end of November.
Siemens welcomed the announcement by IG Metall that it was ready to bring forward talks on the 1997 pay round.

Siemens, which employs 200,000 workers in Germany, was one of the first leading companies to say last week it would impose the cuts in order to cut costs. Unions say that full sick pay is written into their labour contracts.
